ToolStripContentPanel Class

In this Article

Represents the center panel of a ToolStripContainer control.

Syntax

Declaration

[System.ComponentModel.DefaultEvent("Load")]
[System.ComponentModel.Designer("System.Windows.Forms.Design.ToolStripContentPanelDesigner, System.Design, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a")]
[System.ComponentModel.InitializationEvent("Load")]
[System.ComponentModel.ToolboxItem(false)]
[System.Runtime.InteropServices.ClassInterface(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ClassInterfaceType.AutoDispatch)]
[System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisible(true)]
[System.Windows.Forms.Docking(System.Windows.Forms.DockingBehavior.Never)]
public class ToolStripContentPanel : System.Windows.Forms.Panel

Remarks

You can use the top, bottom, left, and right panels of the ToolStripContainer to hold ToolStrip, MenuStrip, or StatusStrip controls. Use the ToolStripContentPanel to hold controls other than these.

    Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

  • OnPaintBackground(PaintEventArgs)

    Renders the ToolStripContentPanel.

    protected override void OnPaintBackground (System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs e);

    Parameters

    • e
      PaintEventArgs

    Remarks

    This method calls ToolStripContentPanelRenderEventArgs, which contains all the information necessary to render the ToolStripContentPanel.

    Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

    The OnPaintBackground method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

  • Load

    Occurs when the content panel loads.

    public event EventHandler Load;

    Remarks

    For more information about handling events, see Events.

    Example

    The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the Load event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing Show with WriteLine or appending the message to a multiline TextBox.

    To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type ToolStripContentPanel named ToolStripContentPanel1. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the Load event. 

    private void ToolStripContentPanel1_Load(Object sender, EventArgs e) {

   MessageBox.Show("You are in the ToolStripContentPanel.Load event.");

}

    Private Sub ToolStripContentPanel1_Load(sender as Object, e as EventArgs) _ 
     Handles ToolStripContentPanel1.Load

   MessageBox.Show("You are in the ToolStripContentPanel.Load event.")

End Sub
